questions.text: A surgeon is performing an axillary dissection for breast cancer and must be cautious not to damage structures piercing the clavipectoral fascia. Which of the following statements about these structures is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: The cephalic vein pierces the clavipectoral fascia and runs through the deltopectoral groove before draining into the axillary vein.

options.label: B
options.text: The thoracoacromial artery pierces the clavipectoral fascia and divides into pectoral, deltoid, acromial, and clavicular branches.

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral pectoral nerve passes through the clavipectoral fascia and innervates the pectoralis minor muscle after piercing the pectoralis major.

options.label: D
options.text: Lymphatic vessels draining the lateral breast region pierce the clavipectoral fascia and drain into the central axillary lymph nodes.

questions.correct_answer: A. The cephalic vein pierces the clavipectoral fascia and runs through the deltopectoral groove before draining into the axillary vein.
questions.explanation:
Feature Description
Location Lies deep to pectoralis major, extends from clavicle to axillary fascia
Pierced by Cephalic vein
Thoracoacromial artery and its branches
Lateral pectoral nerve
Lymphatics from lateral breast
Clinical relevance During axillary dissection, these structures must be protected

Feature Details
Cephalic vein (Option A) Arises from dorsal venous network of the hand
Runs in deltopectoral groove with deltoid branch of thoracoacromial artery
Pierces clavipectoral fascia to drain into axillary vein
Thoracoacromial artery (Option B) Branch of second part of axillary artery
Pierces clavipectoral fascia
Gives off pectoral, deltoid, clavicular, acromial branches (no 'axillary' branch)
Lateral pectoral nerve (Option C)  Arises from lateral cord of brachial plexus
Pierces clavipectoral fascia near thoracoacromial artery
Passes medial to pectoralis minor
Innervates pectoralis major only
Lymphatics (Option D) Drain lateral breast and pectoral region
Pierce clavipectoral fascia to reach apical axillary lymph nodes, not central nodes
Suspensory ligament of axilla Inferior extension of clavipectoral fascia
Anchors axillary fascia to maintain axillary fossa concavity

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the rotator cuff muscles?

options.label: A
options.text: The rotator cuff includes the Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Subscapularis, and Teres major, which collectively aid in shoulder abduction and external rotation.

options.label: B
options.text: The Subscapularis is the only rotator cuff muscle involved in internal rotation of the humerus.

options.label: C
options.text: The Infraspinatus and Teres minor are responsible for medial rotation of the shoulder joint.

options.label: D
options.text: The rotator cuff muscles are primarily located in the anterior aspect of the shoulder joint

questions.correct_answer: B. The Subscapularis is the only rotator cuff muscle involved in internal rotation of the humerus.
questions.explanation:
Muscle (Tendon)

Action

Nerve Supply

Supraspinatus

Initiates abduction of the shoulder

Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6)

Infraspinatus

External( lateral)rotation of the shoulder

Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6)

Teres minor

External(lateral) rotation of the shoulder

Axillary nerve (C5,C6)

Subscapularis

Internal (medial) rotation of the shoulder

Upper and lower subscapular nerves (C5,C6,C7)

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct pairing of shoulder movement and the muscle involved?
questions.explanation:
Movement of the shoulder joint

Muscle(s) Involved

Other movements

Adduction
  • Pectoralis major (Option A)
  • Teres major (Option C)
  • Latissimus dorsi
  • Coracobrachialis
  • Short head of biceps brachii
  • Long head of triceps brachii

Medial rotation of scapula

Abduction
  • Supraspinatus (0-15)  (Option D)
  • Deltoid (15-90)
  • Serratus anterior (90°–180°) (Option B)
  • Upper and lower fibers of trapezius (90°–180°)
  • Humerus elevation
  • Clavicle axial rotation
  • AC joint movement
  • Lateral rotation of scapula

questions.text: Match the wall of the axilla with the structure forming it: Wall Structure forming a. Anterior wall 1. Serratus anterior b. Posterior wall 2. Bicipital groove c. Medial wall 3. Clavipectoral fascia d. Lateral wall 4. Subscapularis
questions.explanation:
Wall of axilla

Contributing structure

Anterior Wall
  • Pectoralis major
  • Clavipectoral fascia
  • Pectoralis minor

Posterior Wall
  • Subscapularis
  • Teres major
  • Latissimus dorsi

Medial Wall
  • Upper four ribs with intercostal muscles
  • Upper part of serratus anterior

Lateral Wall
  • Bicipital groove of humerus
  • Coracobrachialis
  • Short head of biceps brachii

questions.text: Which of the following fasciae is the axillary sheath derived from?
questions.explanation:
Anteriorly

Posterior surface of the clavicle

Posteriorly

Superior border of the scapula and medial aspect of the coracoid process

Medially

Outer border of the first rib

questions.text: A 35-year-old construction worker falls from a ladder and lands on his outstretched hand, resulting in a clavicular fracture as shown in the X- Ray given below. Which ligament plays a crucial role in stabilizing the medial end of the clavicle to the first rib, preventing excessive elevation of the clavicle?
questions.explanation:
Location on Clavicle

Attachment

Lateral End (Acromial end)

Joint capsule of the acromioclavicular joint

Medial End (Sternal end)
  • Fibrous capsule of sternoclavicular joint (all around)
  • Articular disc (posterosuperiorly)
  • Interclavicular ligament (superiorly)

Lateral One-Third of Shaft
  • Anterior border: Origin of deltoid muscle
  • Posterior border: Insertion of trapezius muscle
  • Conoid tubercle and trapezoid ridge: Attachment to the conoid and trapezoid parts of coracoclavicular ligament

Medial Two-Thirds of Shaft
  • Anterior surface: Origin of pectoralis major
  • Rough superior surface: Origin of clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid
  • Oval impression (inferior surface, medial end): Attachment of costoclavicular ligament
  • Subclavian groove: Insertion of subclavius muscle, margins give attachment to clavipectoral fascia
  • Posterior surface (near medial end): Origin of sternohyoid muscle

questions.text: A 45-year-old painter presents with shoulder pain and weakness, particularly when raising his arm. He reports difficulty lifting objects overhead. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the shoulder and weakness in initiating arm abduction. Which rotator cuff muscle is most likely injured?
questions.explanation:
Rotator Cuff Muscles

Muscles and muscle action
  • The rotator cuff consists of four muscles:
    • Supraspinatus: Located above the scapular spine, it aids in arm abduction and is the most commonly injured rotator cuff muscle. (Option C)
    • Infraspinatus: Below the scapular spine, it helps with lateral arm rotation and shoulder stabilization. (Option A ruled out)
    • Teres Minor: Works with the infraspinatus in lateral rotation and stabilizing the shoulder. (Option B ruled out)
    • Subscapularis: On the front of the scapula, it is responsible for medial arm rotation and is the only rotator cuff muscle that doesn’t attach to the greater tubercle of the humerus and forgotten tendon. (Option D ruled out)
  • Musculotendinous Cuff:
    • The tendons of these muscles form the rotator cuff, which supports and stabilizes the shoulder joint during movement.

Functions
  • Stabilize the shoulder.
  • Rotate the arm (medially and laterally).
  • Assist with arm abduction.
  • Control arm movement, especially overhead.

Clinical Relevance
  • Rotator cuff tears: Resulting in pain, weakness, and limited movement.
  • Subacromial bursitis: Inflammation causing shoulder pain and stiffness.
  • Axillary nerve injury: Can weaken shoulder abduction by affecting the deltoid muscle.

Muscle (Tendon)

Action

Nerve supply

Supraspinatus

Initiates abduction of the shoulder

Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6)

Infraspinatus

External and lateral rotation of the shoulder

Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6)

Teres minor

External and lateral rotation of the shoulder

Axillary nerve (C5,C6)

Subscapularis

Internal and medial rotation of the shoulder

Upper and lower subscapular nerves (C5,C6,C7)

questions.text: A 55 year old man, a former construction worker, presents with shoulder pain and limited range of motion. His examination finding is shown below in the image and there is tenderness over the lateral aspect of his ribcage. Which muscle is most likely compromised in function, and what nerve injury could be contributing to his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Pectoralis Major; Medial pectoral nerve injury

options.label: B
options.text: Pectoralis Minor; Lateral pectoral nerve injury

options.label: D
options.text: Serratus Anterior; Long thoracic nerve injury

questions.correct_answer: D. Serratus Anterior; Long thoracic nerve injury
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer :D) Serratus Anterior; Long thoracic nerve injury

Muscles of the Anterior Axioappendicular Region

Muscle

Origin

Insertion

Nerve Supply

Actions

Pectoralis Major (Option A ruled out)
  • Anterior surface of the medial two-thirds of the clavicle
  • Front of the manubrium and sternum up to the 6th costal cartilages
  • Second to sixth costal cartilages and sternal end of the 6th rib
  • Aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle

Lateral lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus (via bilaminar tendon)

Medial and lateral pectoral nerves
  • Adducts and medially rotates the arm
  • Flexes the arm (clavicular part)
  • Extends the flexed arm against resistance (sternocostal part)

 

Pectoralis Minor (Option B ruled out)

3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs near the costochondral junction

Medial border and upper surface of the coracoid process

Medial and lateral pectoral nerves
  • Protracts the scapula
  • Lowers the point of the shoulder

Subclavius (Option C ruled out)

First rib at the costochondral junction

Subclavian groove on the middle third of the clavicle

Nerve to subclavius (from upper trunk of brachial plexus)
  • Stabilizes the clavicle during shoulder movements
  • Protects axillary vessels and brachial plexus

Serratus Anterior (Option D)

Eight digitations from the upper 8 ribs and fascia over the intercostal muscles

Costal surface of the medial border of the scapula

Long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Protracts scapula
  • Rotates scapula upward for arm abduction beyond 90 degrees
  • Stabilizes the scapula during weight-bearing activities
  • Assists in forced inspiration

questions.text: A 35-year-old swimmer presents with weakness during arm extension and difficulty pulling objects toward himself. He also reports pain during forceful expiration, such as coughing or sneezing. Which muscle is most likely involved, and what is its nerve supply?
questions.explanation:
Muscles of the posterior Axioappendicular Region

Muscle

Origin

Insertion

Nerve Supply

Actions

Trapezius (Option A ruled out)
  • Medial one-third of the superior nuchal line of the skull
  • External occipital protuberance
  • Ligamentum nuchae
  • Spinous processes of C7 to T12 vertebrae
  • Corresponding supraspinous ligaments
  • Upper fibers: Posterior border of the lateral one-third of the clavicle
  • Middle fibers: Medial margin of the acromion and upper lip of the spine of the scapula
  • Lower fibers: Apex of a triangular area at the medial end of the spine of the scapula (intervening bursa)
  • Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI)
  • Proprioceptive fibers from C3 and C4.
  • Upper fibers: Elevate the scapula (shoulder shrugging), extend the neck (bilaterally)
  • Middle fibers: Retract the scapula
  • Lower fibers: Rotate the scapula upward, aiding arm abduction beyond 90 degrees
  • Trapezius with rhomboids: Retract scapula and tilt glenoid inferiorly.
  • Trapezius with serratus anterior: Overhead abduction and tilt glenoid superiorly.
  • All fibers together: Stabilize the scapula during arm movements

Latissimus Dorsi (Option B)
  • Posterior one-third of the outer lip of the iliac crest
  • Posterior layer of lumbar fascia (connecting to lumbar and sacral spines)
  • Spinous processes of T7 to T12
  • Lower four ribs
  • Inferior angle of the scapula

Fibers twist to insert into the floor of the intertubercular sulcus of the humerus, wrapping around the lower border of the teres major.

Thoracodorsal nerve (C6, C7, C8).
  • Extends, adducts, and medially rotates the arm (e.g., swimming, climbing)
  • Assists in forceful expiration (e.g., coughing, sneezing)

Levator Scapulae (Option D ruled out)

Transverse processes of C1 to C4 vertebrae

Superior angle and upper part of the medial border of the scapula

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5) and branches from C3 and C4

Elevates and stabilizes the scapula during arm movements.

Rhomboid Minor (Option C ruled out)

Lower part of ligamentum nuchae and spinous processes of C7 and T1

Medial border of the scapula at the base of the triangular area at the root of the spine.

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Retracts and stabilizes the scapula.

Rhomboid Major

Spinous processes of T2 to T5 and supraspinous ligaments

Medial border of the scapula, below the root of the spine

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Retracts and stabilizes the scapula.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presents to the ED with a tension pneumothorax. The physician decides to perform a chest drain insertion to relieve the pressure. As the physician prepares for the procedure, they review the anatomical landmarks to ensure they insert the drain safely. Which muscle defines the posterior boundary of the Triangle of Safety, ensuring that the physician avoids vital structures during the chest drain insertion?
questions.explanation:
Anteriorly

Lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle.

Posteriorly

Lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle.

Inferiorly

A horizontal line at the level of the 5th intercostal space (usually aligned with the nipple in males).

Superiorly

Base of the axilla(armpit).

questions.text: Which muscle forms the medial border of the Triangle of Auscultation?
questions.explanation:
Medial Border

Lateral border of the trapezius muscle.

Lateral Border

Medial border of the scapula.

Inferior Border

Superior border of the latissimus dorsi muscle.

Anterior or floor

Rhomboid major, 6th and 7th ribs.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for winging of scapula?
Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the muscles involved in abduction of shoulder?

options.label: A
options.text: Supraspinatous is involved in initiation of abduction.

options.label: B
options.text: Deltoid is responsible for 0-15 degree abduction.

options.label: C
options.text: Supraspinatous is responsible for 15-90 degree abduction.

options.label: D
options.text: Infraspinatous is responsible for 0-15 degree abduction.

questions.correct_answer: A. Supraspinatous is involved in initiation of abduction.
questions.explanation:
Shoulder abduction
  • Supraspinatus (0-15)
  • Deltoid (15-90)
  • Serratus anterior (90°-180°)
  • Upper and lower fibers of trapezius (90°-180°)
